title: stalker teen who followed ex
story: Stalker teen who followed ex to Benidorm scratched nonce into his car after breakupChloe Armes, , was furious after -year-old David McDermott ended their relationship and smashed windows at his ex-partners home when he broke up with her, a court heardDavid McDermott told Chloe Armes to stop contacting him after she posted on Facebook saying she was pregnant Image: Chloe Armes  Cavendish PressLtdByEthan DaviesGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA stalker teen followed her former lover to Benidorm and scratched aposnonceapos on his car bonnet after they broke up. She met David McDermott at a pub in summer  and they began a relationship in  just weeks after her th birthday. But the -year-old was furious after the -year-old ended their relationship and smashed windows at his ex-partneraposs home. Before their affair, Armes and McDermott knew each other from Eccles College, where he had been her student support officer.And their relationship started after the pair later met at a pub, the Manchester Evening News reports. Armes followed him outside and told him she had aposfantasisedapos about the pair having sex, prosecutor Gavin Howie told Manchester Crown Court. He says that he took her to the Ivy Mount Hotel and had sex with her, Mr Howie said, according to Manchester Evening News.The following day, he says, he transferred money to her bank account for drugs she supplied him. Mr Howie said Mr McDermott admitted he had been drinking heavily and took cocaine, which the man put down to his poor mental health. His mental health continued to be an issue after their first encounter, Mr Howie added. He says he was struggling with his mental health so he went to Benidorm [alone] and drank and took drugs, the prosecution added. He received a payment of four pence and one pence [from the defendant] saying aposcall me nowapos and aposbell me nowapos. He says she came to Benidorm but, he says, nothing happened while she was there. After the trip, Armes, of St Marys Road, Eccles, rang Mr McDermottaposs ex-partner — the mother of his children. Following this, contact between the pair ceased for some weeks until Armes emailed Mr McDermott in September , claiming to be apossleeping roughapos. He did not reply, Mr Howie told Her Honour Manley. He rang her the following day and told her to stop emailing.  They arranged a meeting in the Milton Hotel [in order] to aposget what she wantedapos. They had unprotected sex. She was annoyed that he brought protection.She then placed material on Facebook saying she was pregnant.This incident was the last time the pair had sex, as Mr McDermott told Armes to stop contacting him. In November , Armes then messaged his ex-partner about their relationship, who confronted him. Armes also told his employer and McDermott was later sacked from this position for gross misconduct. Despite this, Armes continued to message and call Mr McDermott — leading him to change his mobile number three times, after she repeatedly contacted him on unknown numbers, or by using someone ’s phone. The court heard how Armes later went to his ex-partner’s house while Mr McDermott was visiting, then damaged windows, and scratched the word ‘nonce’ into his car bonnet. The window damage came to £ and car damage to £. Representing Armes was Jayne Miller, who told the court her client had a troubled upbringing, with the family forced to relocate to Wales after being fire-bombed. “She has had a dficult background,” Ms Miller said. “Her family were firebombed, and were moved out of Salford to Wales, into a one-bedroom property and [were] not able to leave each others’ company, being protected by the safeguarding team. “She came back one year later and went to a dferent school. She is young and socially isolated and has what appears to be emotionally unstable personality disorder.” Ms Miller added that Armes now says she ‘hates’ Mr McDermott, and does not wish to be in contact with him again. Sentencing her to a community order and restraining order, judge Hilary Manley said she offered Armes ‘a chance’. “You are clearly remorseful and have made efforts to improve your future,” she said. “There can be no excuse for harassing any person. It is totally destructive and pointless. Your actions also caused distress to his children. That is unacceptable. I am giving you this chance. Do not squander it.” Armes pleaded guilty to one count of stalking. She was sentenced to a two-year community order, with  rehabilitation days, and handed an indefinite restraining order against the victim and his family.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BenidormCrown court" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: teacher 29 makes history after
story: Teacher, , makes history after shes spotted playing football with kids at car washAmy Gillingham, , from Southport in Merseyside, moved to the Unites Arab Emirates in  and was playing football with kids at a car wash in the Middle Eastern country when she was offered TV workAmy Gillingham, , from Southport, Merseyside, moved to the UAE in  Image: LiverpoolEcho  WSByBenjamin Roberts-HaslamRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A woman has made history after a TV executive scouted her while she was playing football with local kids at a car wash in the United Arab Emirates. Amy Gillingham, , moved from Southport moved to the Middle Eastern country in  after being offered a job as a PE teacher in the Middle Eastern country.She took the dream job but is now creating history in a dream role after she became the first female commentator on a major football event in the UAE earlier this month. As a youngster Amy played for Liverpool Feds and FC United of Manchesteraposs womenaposs football teams before making the move abroad. But her big break came while she was waiting for her car to be washed. She was playing football with some of the local kids and staff when a man approached her. They chatted about the game for ten minutes when he revealed he worked for a TV company and offered her a chance to work on a UAE football match in the future.Speaking to the Liverpool Echo, Amy said: So originally I came out here as a PE teacher working in the government schools. I was a little bit more than a PE teacher as I was looking after schools. Iaposd go in, help and support the PE teachers, upskill them and then develop the curriculum. I moved out here around five years ago and moving on from that Iaposve always loved my football. I was getting my car washed one day. I was waiting for my car to be done when I started playing football with some of the workers and children that were there and then a chap came over and we started talking all things football. He said that he did this, that and the other working in the football commentary world and askedI would be interested. I was like aposye, of course, football is my dream!apos. Anything to do with football, talking about football, is an absolute dream come true. A couple of months went by and I just thought it must have been put to bed and may happen in the near future. Then a couple of weeks ago I got a phone call asking me to commentate on the Super Cup Final which is a huge game out here for the local professional league. I did that and now Iaposve signed a contract with the UAE Pro League commentating within the league. Itaposs mental! Amy has been obsessed with the sport since she was a kid, with her competitiveness stemming from her relationship with her older brother. She officially became the first female commentator in the UAE on Friday, January  when Al Jazira took on Shabab Al-Ahli. She co-commentated with journalist and broadcaster Graham Clews ahead of signing a contract with the UAE Pro League. She said: Iaposve got an older brother so we were always kicking a ball about in the back garden with him and that led on to playing in school, then local clubs in Southport such as Birkdale and Southport FC. From there I ventured out to Liverpool where I played for Liverpool Feds. I then went to Manchester to play for FC United of Manchester. Iaposve always been involved in football and from there got into coaching roles and when I was in university Iaposd support local schools with coaching. Itaposs always been there. Itaposs in my blood, to be honest. news uk-news terrying-cctv-footage-shows-moment-"Birmingham: CCTV captures car crashing into houseByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsCCTV footage shows the dramatic moment an out of control car speeds down a hill and smashed into a parked car, shunting it through the front of a house.The terrying footage shows the crash in Northfield, Birmingham, in the early hours of Saturday morning. As most residents slept soundly, a car sped down the hill, which is known to be icy, toward the junction. Instead of slowing and turning, the car shoots across the road and into the parked car opposite. It hits the vehicle with such force that it shunts the car through the front of the house, smashing the wall and window inwards.  Then, the driver can be seen leaping from the wreckage, and running away. Emergency services were called to the road at am today, to be greeted by the horric crash scene. Thankfully no one was hurt, but neighbours were awoken by the sound of the impact and the car alarm that followed. A number of residents went to investigate and were shocked to find the car empty, with the airbags activated and the keys still in the ignition.  They tried to alert the people inside the home, thankfully, all of whom were uninjured. When emergency services arrived, the road was blocked off and police attempted to locate the driver.The damage to the house is not believed to be structural and West Midlands police are continuing their inquiries to locate the driver.They have urged anyone with information to come forward.  A West Midlands Police spokesperson said: We were called to Cheverton Road, Birmingham at am this morning to reports a car had collided with another car that had crashed into the side of a house. The occupants of the house were not hurt and there is not believed to be any structural damage to the house. Enquiries are ongoing to trace the driver of the car who left before emergency services attended the scene. title: wetherspoons open first uni pub
story: Wetherspoons to open first uni pub where students can drink coffee all day for pStudents will be able to drink unlimited coffee for p and get all the usual Wetherspoons offerings, including a £. breakfast at the Sanctuary pub in HullWetherspoons to open its first pub on a uni campus Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByIvan Morris PoxtonKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPub giant Wetherspoons is opening its first ever pub on the grounds of a British university. Itaposs first on-campus bar is the result of a partnership between the pub and hotel chain and Hull University Studentsapos Union. Students will be able to drink unlimited coffee for p and get all the usual Wetherspoons offerings, including a £. breakfast at the Sanctuary pub. It had previously been reported on social media that Wetherspoons might be set to take over a student bar on campus. And now the University of Hull has confirmed the partnership between the studentsapos union and the chain.Jeremy Hartley, chief finance officer at the University of Hull with responsibility for commercial services, told Hull Live : We know that our students really value having all the facilities they need in one place. Our single-site campus provides our community with study spaces, food and drink establishments, gym and sports facilities and much more. This announcement further enhances that student experience, providing students with a quality, affordable food and events space right on their doorstep. Our campus is what makes the University of Hull the wonderful place it is, and this new partnership emphasises the importance of providing students with the very best experience possible. Bar staff will continue to be employed by HUSU, but will get the same training and induction as Wetherspoon staff nationwide. A Wetherspoon spokeswoman said: We have entered into a partnership with Hull University Students Union for the operation of the Sanctuary Bar and we look forward to working with them to making it a success. news us-news woman-branded-fat-doctors-pregnant-"Woman shares symptoms of having oian cystByNia PriceGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA woman was branded aposfatapos by doctors until a five stone cyst was discovered. Crystal Dominguez claims she started having irregular periods, sharp stomach pains and abdominal swelling back in late  but was told by doctors that she just needed to lose weight. Her stomach swelled so badly she looked like she was expecting triplets. The -year-old said her stomach ballooned so large that people thought she was expecting and kept asking aposwhen are you due apos, so to avoid aposuncomfortableapos questions and stares she became housebound for months. But just when the singleton had aposlost hopeapos of receiving help, a aposbasketball-sizedapos cyst was eventually discovered on her oy in October , which was surgically removed shortly after. Crystal, who works in social media marketing and is a passionate advocate for womenaposs health care, urges other women to get their symptoms checked out andthey feel like theyaposre not being heard - visit another doctor. Crystal, of Murfreesboro, Tennessee, US, said: When I got my scans they told me my cyst was the size of a basketball and a week later when I got out of surgery Iaposd lost  pounds of fluid from my stomach. After my surgery my surgeon came into my room and told me that I was lucky becausethat cyst would have ruptured they would not have been able to save me because it was that big. A cyst can rupture doing anything and at that time I was going to the gym twice a day. It was a ticking time bomb, she said. It was crazy. I feel like that was a sign that Iaposm meant to be on this earth to hopefully help someone  because I could have died in so many ways and I didnapost. The college graduate said she went to the doctor when she first developed symptoms and was told that they were aposnormalapos due to her birth control. Crystal said: My periods were very irregular and always heavy. I had weight gain in my stomach. It would never go away and it wasnapost normal fat where Iaposd have rolls. My stomach was very hard and smooth. It looked really round to the point where I looked like I was pregnant with like three babies beyond full term. I also had very sharp stomach pains. It wouldnapost be all the time it was sometimes in my lower stomach and then it was really tight.  Crystal claims that after having her birth control removed her symptoms persisted and she ed to the doctors who advised her that just needed to lose weight. Crystal said: The doctors essentially said aposyouaposre just fatapos. They sent me to a nutritionist and that was it. That was basically their version of saying that I was big and thataposs all. A lot of them told me that I needed to start to work out and change my eating habits. They didnapost even bother to examine my stomach.  I explained my symptoms to them but I felt like they wouldnapost hear me or care. I also felt like I wasnapost heard because of me being a mixed [race] woman. I felt like they didnapost pay attention to me. It was really hard and depressing. I went to doctors and they really just convinced me I was fat. I wouldnapost leave the house because I was embarrassed. I went to the gym twice a day. I ate but didnapost eat enough. I was always like aposok, I canapost eat because Iaposm too fatapos. Crystal said that the weight of the cyst meant that her back hurt all the time and she couldnapost stand for long periods. She said: Everybody thought I was carrying a child so then theyaposd always ask me questions like aposoh my God, youaposre pregnant  When are you due apos and things like that which made me uncomfortable to the point I didnapost leave the house for months. People would stare and come up to me and touch my stomach and it would just be very uncomfortable. I would tell them I wasnapost pregnant and it would just get awkward and weird. I didnapost even want to go to the doctor anymore because I lost hope. But my mom was like aposno, weaposre going to go to the doctor one last time and they are going to do somethingapos. I was relieved [to receive diagnosis] because I was like aposok, this is good because Iaposm not crazyapos. Something was wrong with me when all these doctors made me feel really crazy but then also it was really terrying because I was like aposoh my Gosh, that is hugeapos. Crystal said her oian cystadenoma diagnosis arose after she visited another doctor who could see how round her stomach was so gave her an ultrasound in October . This was followed by a scan two days later and she had surgery to remove the fluid along with one of her oies that had been aposcrushedapos by the cyst a week later. It was then sent off to ensure it wasnapost cancerous and it was discovered to be benign. The -year-old said it took her three to four weeks to be able to walk again and she was fully healed after around eight weeks. Crystal said: Once it was removed it was super scary because the cyst pushed out all my organs and ribs so afterwards was horrible. I would stand up and it would feel like all of my organs were coming out of my body and it was painful because they were trying to move back in my body. I felt my insides move and itaposs just the weirdest feeling to describe. At first I was really embarrassed [to share experience online] because of my photos I thought I looked really fat but I have to realise that I survived this and went through this for a reason and I truly believe that my reason was to be able to help someone . Iaposd say to other women that you know your body better than anyone  in the whole world andyou feel like something is wrong please, from the bottom of my heart, go and get checked out. Anda doctor doesnapost listen to you, go to someone  and keep doing that until you find someone. You have to fight for yourself. title: cats hold owners kitchen blender
story: Cats hold owners kitchen blender hostage for a month in hilarious standoffJessica and Nikki Gerson-Neeves treated themselves to a new blender in December last year and couldnt wait to get it open - but after their cats took a liking to its box, they found themselves in a stalemateThe cats have been holding the box hostage for a month Image: Jessica Gerson-NeeveByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsAs we get older, there are few things more exciting than buying a new piece of kit for the kitchen. So when married couple Jessica and Nikki Gerson-Neeves bought themselves a new blender last month, they couldnapost wait to take it out of the box and start making smoothies. But after temporarily leaving the box on the floor of the kitchen, Jessica, from Vancouver Island in Canada, went to open it to find it had attracted an admirer - the coupleaposs four-year-old cat, Max.Max had decided to get comfortable on top of the box and settle in for a few hours. Thinking his fascination was cute, Jessica took a photo of Max on the box and uploaded it to a Facebook group for chunky cats.As Max perched high up on the box and surveyed his territory, he attracted the attention of his kitty siblings, George and Lando Calrissian, both .For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Soon, the cats had knocked Max off his perch and each taken their turns sitting on top of the box - which became something of a vicious cycle. And a month after they bought the blender, Nikki and Jessica still havenapost been able to unpack it. In what has now become a turf war, the three cats spend their days knocking each other off the blender box to nab their turn - and according to the couple, itaposs never left unattended. The pair now document the standoff - dubbed aposappliancegateapos - on their Facebook page, which has amassed , followers since they first posted updates a month ago.  Included in the updates are videos of the cats fighting over the blender box to win their turn sitting on top of it. Speaking to npr, Jessica said she and Nikki didnapost realise their updates would win so many viewers around the world, but added theyaposre both pleased to be bringing people some comic relief during dark times. She said: It is silly and ridiculous and very low stakes and not an actual problem and just something that people can laugh at. Followers of the saga have commented on the Facebook page to share their amusement at the updates.  One person wrote: I just found this story today and I’ve been laughing so much, so thank you! I will follow your cats forever. Another loyal fan said: I just boasted to my husband that I’ve been on this ride from Day One. He thinks I’m nuts, but my cat doesn’t judge. While people as far away as Australia and Italy have been captivated by the stand-off, theyaposre also offering Jessica and Nikki light-hearted solutions to end the stalemate. The plans include digging a tunnel underneath the ground to extract the blender from below, and even buying three more blenders, so they can give each cat a perch and rescue the original utensil they are still yet to use. The saga even attracted the attention of Vitamix, the company that produces the blender, which tried to offer a solution and sent an identical blender box to the household. Although Jessica admitted she and Nikki could end appliancegate by lting the cats off the box, fans have asked them to let the cats carry on purely for the entertainment factor. She said: Certainly we could relocate them. They donapost weigh a ton. It would be very easy to pick whoeveraposs on the box up and put them on the floor and open the box. But why would we end something that is bringing us so much laughter  Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Animals" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i uninvited stepdad wedding because
story: I uninvited my stepdad from my wedding because of my brothers - even though he paid for itAn anonymous bride has taken to Reddit to explain why she uninvited her stepdad from her wedding after her brothers gave her an ultimatum - but now shes worried shes made the wrong decisionA bride to be is in a dilemma about her wedding invitations Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A bride-to-be has revealed she uninvited her stepdad from her wedding, even though he paid for it, because her brothers wouldnapost attendhe was there.The woman, who is  years old, says she and her older brothers had a rough time when their parents got orced, before their mum met their stepdad and he moved in. In a post on Reddit, the bride said: [My brothers] never had a good relationship because they never wanted my mum and dad to separate in the first place. They resented my stepdad and limited contact once they moved out. However, while the older brothers cut ties with their stepdad, the bride explains she continued to foster a relationship with him as she spent more time with him.  She wrote: We established a somewhat stable relationship. The bride added her stepdad had helped her out with her schooling, and that he had even offered to fund her wedding. Iaposm very grateful for that though it was his decision, she wrote. She then explains she sent her older brothers invitations to the wedding - but as soon as they found out their stepdad was attending, they said they might not come. After taking time to think, the bride says her brothers confronted her with an ultimatum - that they wouldnapost attend the weddingtheir stepdad was also going.  She wrote: I literally freaked out because I definatelywant my brothers to be at my wedding so badly and I tried talking to them but they were being stubborn. After talking to my fiance I had no choice but to politely un-invite my stepdad and sending him an email stating why. After sending the email, the bride claims her mum called her and shouted at her, suggesting she was ungrateful for excluding her stepdad after everything heaposs done for her. She claims she explained to her mum that her brothers had given her an ultimatum, but her mum wasnapost buying her excuse. Instead, she scolded her daughter for prioritising her hateful and cold-hearted brothers over her stepdad and showing she was not worthy of his grace. The bride said it was really really hurtful for her to hear her mumaposs harsh words. After she hung up I asked my fianceI made the wrong decision and he said itaposs my wedding and I get to decide, she wrote. However, she added her fiancé is biased and is expected to be on her side. After asking for opinions on whether or not she was in the wrong, people commented on her story to give their verdict. One person said the bride was in the wrong for letting her brothers control her decision. They wrote: Your mothers words hurt because they are true. Another said: I would understandthe step dad was abusive or condescending. But this time it’s on the brothers. news weird-news man-bemused-after-finding-hes-"TikToker spoilt rotten by cabin crew after being alone on flightByJohn BettAudience WriterSofie JacksonVideo News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A man was left bemused after getting on a plane and finding he was the only passenger onboard - and he was then doted on by the cabin crew. Kai Forsyth, said it was the weirdest experience to be on the British Airways flight alone, but added heaposd never been comfier as he set up a bed across a few of the seats. He said he was given all the food that he wanted on the flight from London to Orlando, Florida, and cabin crew explained that no other passengers were on the plane, as the Daily Star reports. Kai, from Debry, shared his experience on TikTok, where he uploads to the account @kaorsyth, and now heaposs gone viral as fans canapost believe his luck. Whataposs your most unusual travel experience  Let us know in the comments...In the social media clip, Kai said: The cabin crew said I was the only person on board the flight. He said that he decided to put the armrests down and get comfy with a makesht bed across four empty seats. It was eight hours so I set up a bed. Literally the comfiest Iaposve ever been on a plane, he writes on the screen. Kai also shows how he was given a wholesale box full of Walkers shortbread biscuits since there was nobody  to cater for. They literally gave me all the snacks and unlimited food, he writes while making his viewersapos mouths water with jealousy. He said he couldnapost be upgraded to business or first class which was the only downside to his enjoyable trip. The video was watched more than , times and people said Kai was very lucky, although one confessed they found it a bit scary and said: Nah Iaposd be too paranoid the whole journey. A second viewer shared: I remember the flight home from JFK to Gatwick, about  people the whole of economy. Was the best flight. Omg that was me I kept flying when Covid first ever got announced and there were no restrictions, someone  commented. Another user said: The last time it happened to me it was the roughest flight ever and landed on nd attempt.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: man earns 160 day standing
story: Man earns £ a day by standing in line for rich people - so they dont have toFreddie Beckitt, , said that as a Londoner, queueing comes naturally to him so he decided to turn it into a career and now he stands in line for other peopleFreddit Beckitt is a professional queuer, and stands in line all day long Image: Getty ImagesByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A man has become a professional queuer and earns his money by standing in line for rich people who donapost want to - and heaposs making a killing doing it.Freddie Beckitt charges £ an hour to stand in line for other people, and he says it comes naturally to him as heaposs a Londoner, and has queueing down to a fine art. On a good day, the -year-old can earn up to £, but he must have the patience of a saint as that means heaposs stood in a line, barely moving, for a full eight hours. Freddie, from Fulham, said that his best jobs are queueing for tickets to highly popular events, such as performances at the Apollo, for customers who are money-rich and time-poor. What do you think about Freddieaposs unique job  Let us know in the comments...Speaking to The Sun, Freddie said: I worked eight hours for a job queuing for the VAaposs Christian Dior exhibition for some very well-to-do people around their mid-sixties. The actual queuing was just three hours but they asked me to collect their tickets too and wait for them to arrive, so I just had hours perusing the VA museum being paid £ an hour, it was great! Freddieaposs clients y from young families who are run off their feet to OAPaposs - and heaposs spent freezing winter nights in queues. The lad advertises on Taskrabbit where he also advertises pet sitting, packing, errands and gardening. He commented: Honestly it came about by just stretching around here, there and everywhere, Taskrabbit enables you to list ious dferent odd jobs and clients just select you from the roles youaposve listed.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news man-finds-picture-hovering-ufo-"A brief history of UFO SightingsByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A man thinks he may have found solid evidence of a UFO after spotting an odd shape hovering over Antarctica while searching through Google Maps. A screengrab of the image shows a white cylindrical object on a brown background which appear to be rocks located at .S, .W, which is along the edge of the snowy land, as the Daily Star reports.Reddit user @Leesoy posted the image and asked others for their opinion, as he thought what he had seen could be a UFO in flight. This discovery comes after a series of UFO sightings have been made around the world and speculation that aliens are visiting us is on the rise. What do you think of the sighting  Let us know in the comments...Sharing a picture, the user asked: Ufo or rock  Antarctica google earth.UFO sightings have been on the rise in the past few years, as recently an airman witnessed a aposUFOapos while he was guarding nuclear weapons at a US Air Force base - adding that heaposs seen aposshadow peopleapos at similar installations.Former USAF nuclear weapons technician Adrian Reister said that between  and  he was stationed at Whiteman Air Force Base, Missouri, where he would guard, maintain, and move nuclear weapons. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. He said that while performing his duties, he saw a glowing aposorbapos hovering above a nearby treeline before flying off. Adrian, , said that it couldnapost have been one of their planes as he knew them all extensively, and he added that while he was training at a similar station he came face-to-face with a terrying ft aposshadow personapos. And here in the UK, a man claimed to have seen a triangular aposUFOapos with aposcloaking abilitiesapos on New Yearaposs Eve - in a sighting that is eerily similar to one made in Britain just a few months ago.UFO enthusiast Vaultteam managed to capture a video of the mysterious object flying over Columbus Ohio, and it shows three lights floating in a triangular shape. The clip is very similar to a video captured by a doorbell camera in Britain in November, as Matt Doughty, , was baffled by a strange triangular object gliding over his house in St Albans, Hertfordshire. The new sighting, which has been shared on Reddit, left the witness shocked as the lights suddenly disappeared - leaving him to think the UFO has the ability to make itself invisible.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: mum baffled pink egg frying
story: Mum baffled by pink egg in frying pan - and shes warned not to eat itBeena Sarangdhar screamed after cracking an egg into a frying pan as it was completely pink, and after she shared a snap of it online she was warned not to eat itBeena Sarangdhar was horried after finding a pink egg in her frying panByJohn BettAudience WriterAdam May:,  Jan | comments A mum was left baffled after cracking eggs into a frying pan to make breakfast for her children - as one of the yolks was completely pink.Beena Sarangdhar, from Abbots Langley, Hertfordshire, screamed when she made the unusual discovery, but soon her horror turned to curiosity and she cracked the rest of the eggs.To her surprise, all the rest of them were fine so she took a photo of the pink egg and shared it online - and soon others were warning her not to eat it, as Herts Live reports. Beena told her children to stay away and did some research, and it emerged that the egg had turned pink due to a bacteria that can lead to serious illness in humans. What do you think of the pink egg  Let us know in the comments...Beena said: I fancied some egg yesterday and cracked open the egg in the frying pan as normal. Then as it fell into the pan I screamed as I have never seen a pink egg before. The kids came running to see what had happened and their reaction was typical, [they went] aposerrrrapos. Beena then found that the other eggs were completely fine - but it was something she had definitely never seen before. She added: I then cracked the other two eggs from the same box but they were normal. It was really weird because they were in date and just the last few left. Bought them from the local Asda in Watford. It did put me off for a second but after that everyone fancied some egg on toast! According to the US Department of Agriculture, a cloudy egg white is a sign the egg is very fresh, and a clear egg white is an indication the egg is ageing. But Pink or pearly egg whites indicate spoilage due to Pseudomonas bacteria, which can lead to headaches, swelling, and even pneumonia. Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: ashling murphy devastating empty chair
story: Ashling Murphy: Devastating empty chair and fiddle tribute to woman killed while joggingIrish police are continuing to hunt for the killer of Ashling Murphy who was found dead on Wednesday after going for a run on the banks of the Grand Canal in Cappincur, TullamoreA tribute to Ashling Murphy who absolutely loved her fiddle Image: TwitterByShauna Bannon WardDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Jan A devastating tribute was paid to a young woman who was murdered while out jogging in Ireland. Irish police are continuing to hunt for the killer of Ashling Murphy who was found dead on Wednesday after going for a run on the banks of the Grand Canal in Cappincur, Tullamore.In The Late Late Show’s tribute to Ashling, traditional Irish musicians joined together to celebrate their music and memorialise the primary school teacher, RSVP reports. Mike Hanrahan from Stocktonaposs Wing, Beogaaposs Niamh Dunne, Dara and Mick Healy from Boxing Banjo, Bridín, Mairead Ni Mhaonaigh and Séamus and Caoimhe Ui Fhlatharta were present in the musical sessions. Many people pointed out a touching part of the tribute with a chair holding a fiddle and bow dedicated to Ashling, who absolutely loved her fiddle. One person wrote: “The empty chair for Aisling is both devastating and beautul.” A second viewer said: “The empty chair for Aisling is beautul but heartbreaking. Ireland united in grief for its devastating loss.” A third commenter shared: “Powerful soothing soulful traditional music and song on The @RTELateLateShow tonight to remember, celebrate and offer sympathies for the beautul le of Ashling Murphy that was taken so senselessly. “The fiddle on the empty chair was such a poignant image.” Those who watched the moving performances shared how heartbreaking the programme was.  One RTE viewer said: “Beautul  moving musical tribute to Ashling Murphy on the #Latelateshow. Heartbreaking to see empty chair with fiddle.” A second person wrote: “The empty chair  fiddle is truly heartbreaking. Rest in Peace Ashling Murphy”. Attracta Brady, who was Ms Murphyaposs first fiddle teacher, played alongside other sombre performers at a vigil on Friday evening. She was the most beautul girl inside and out, Ms Brady said.  She was a parentaposs dream. She was everything youaposd want in a daughter. She had integrity, she was honest, she was trustworthy. She was quirky and a little bit cheeky sometimes with the loveliest smile and sheaposd get away with it because she had this beautul twinkly smile. She was never in bad humour, she was always smiling and she absolutely loved her fiddle. Her parents only told me yesterday that she never had to be told to practice. She was bright and energetic and everybody loved her. Police arrested a man following the attack, although he has since been released and is no longer a suspect in the case, the Irish Mirror reports.Officers yesterday announced that a new suspect has been identied and a new line of inquiry is being followed.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON MurderPoliceCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: pioneering-glasgow-doctor-margaret-kerr-saved-lives-hundreds-premature-babies
story: COMPASSIONATE and dedicated, Dr Margaret Kerr’s work in Glasgow saved the lives of hundreds of premature babies. The consultant paediatrician at what was then the Royal Hospital for Sick Children at Yorkhill was a leading light in neo-natal medicine. She once said in an interview with the Evening Times: “I love babies – we are no longer just saving le but producing healthy future citizens. That gives us all pride and pleasure.”

story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. title: farmers face fertiliser price standoff
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: 3m helping hand for scottish households amid surging energy costs
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: sweet treats vegan chocolate orange pots recipe
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. title: 5 fitness trends to watch out for in 2022
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
